nodes.text: A decision tree classifier (J48/C4.5) can be used to predict diabetes status from the Pima Indian dataset with high accuracy
Data mining classification techniques are appropriate for medical disease prediction tasks such as diabetes detection
We used the Pima Indian Diabetes dataset (768 female subjects, 8 input numeric attributes, binary class) as the data source
We used the J48 implementation of C4.5 in the WEKA environment to build a decision tree model using entropy and information gain for attribute selection
Model evaluation used a confusion matrix reporting true positives, true negatives, false positives, false negatives and overall accuracy
Classification aims to build a predictive model from labeled examples to assign class labels to unseen instances

Dataset details: 768 records, attributes include pregnancy count, plasma glucose, diastolic BP, skinfold thickness, serum insulin, BMI, diabetes pedigree, age; class has 268 positives and 500 negatives
J48 builds a top-down decision tree using normalized information gain (difference in entropy) to choose split attributes and can prune after creation
WEKA Explorer GUI was used to load the ARFF dataset, select the J48 tree, run training and testing, and visualize the resulting tree
Entropy for the class distribution was computed as 0.9328 and attribute information gains were computed to select the root attribute
A decision tree model was generated and visualized in WEKA for the diabetes prediction task
Experimental evaluation produced overall accuracy 84.1146%, with TP=468, TN=178, FP=32, FN=90, and error rate 15.8854%
Sample preprocessing note: dataset contains zero values indicating missing measurements (e.g., 5 glucose=0, 11 BMI=0, 28 diastolic BP=0, 192 skinfold=0, 140 insulin=0)
Calculated attribute gains: plasma glucose gain 0.1332, BMI gain 0.0724, pregnancy gain 0.0366, leading to selection of plasma glucose as a strong splitting attribute
Compared to a referenced existing method, the proposed J48 model increased accuracy by 0.48% (from 83.63% to 84.1146%) while increasing model build time by 0.02 seconds
After deleting records with missing values, only 392 complete cases remain (103 positive, 262 negative), so missing value handling is necessary for exact prediction and future work
